Of, pertaining to, or powered by atomic energy; same as nuclear-powered; as, a nuclear submarine; a nuclear power plant.
Of or pertaining to nations possessing nuclear weapons; as, the nuclear club.

entry.def: an explosive device, whether used as a weapon or for other purposes, which depends for most of its explosive power on the release of energy from within atomic nuclei. A fission device or a fusion device.
Energy derived from nuclear reactions; -- used at present especially of electrical power generated in atomic reactors, but encompassing also fusion energy.
entry.syn: atomic energy, atomic power, nuclear energy, nuclear power.

entry.def: The branch of engineering concerned with the design and construction and operation of nuclear reactors.
The explosion of an atomic bomb or atomic device; -- sometimes also used of fusion-powered explosions.
A family consisting of parents and their children and grandparents of a marital partner.
A nuclear reaction in which a heavy atomic nucleus splits into smaller nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy.
A type of nuclear reaction in which atomic nuclei combine to form more massive nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy.
A nuclear reaction in which nuclei combine to form more massive nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy.

The specific absorption and re-emission of electromagnetic radiation at characteristic wavelengths by atomic nuclei in a magnetic field. It is abbreviated NMR. The wavelength of the radiation absorbed depends on the type of nucleus, the intensity of the magnetic field, and the local chemical environment in which the nucleus resides. It is the latter effect (called the chemical shift), by which atoms of specific elements in different chemical compounds show a different resonance frequency, which gives rise to the greatest utility of this phenomenon in analyzing the chemical structure of substances. Similar effects of the chemical environment permit the discrimination of different types of living tissue by virtue of their different chemical composition, thus permitting utilization of the phenomenon in medical diagnostic instruments, especially for magnetic resonance imaging.
That branch of physics which studies the structure of and phenomena observed in atomic nuclei.
A scientist specializing in nuclear physics.

sn.def: Power derived from nuclear reactions; -- used at present especially of electrical power generated in atomic reactors, but encompassing also fusion power.
sn.syn: atomic energy, atomic power, nuclear energy, nuclear energy.

sn.def: A country possessing nuclear weapons.

entry.def: A ship for which the motive power comes from the energy generated by a nuclear reactor.
A submarine for which the motive power comes from the energy generated by a nuclear reactor. Same as nuclear submarine.
A process that alters the energy or structure or composition of an atomic nucleus.

Any of several devices that maintain and control a sustained nuclear fission chain reaction, for the production of energy, heat, or artificial elements, or for research purposes. The main fuel sustaining the reaction and consumed by the process is typically uranium or plutonium.
entry.syn: reactor, atomic pile, fission reactor, nuclear pile

entry.def: The resonance absorption of a gamma ray by a nucleus identical to the nucleus that emitted the gamma ray.

A war in which nuclear weapons are used by both sides. As generally used, the term assumes major use of nuclear weapons by at least two opposing warring states. As of 1999, no nuclear war has occurred.
The warhead of a missile containing an atom bomb or hydrogen bomb.

A weapon of great explosive power, such as an atomic bomb or a hydrogen bomb, which depends for most of its explosive power on the release of energy from within atomic nuclei by a nuclear reaction. A fission weapon or a fusion weapon. The term includes atomic shells for cannon.

a hypothetical lowering of global temperature postulated as the aftermath of a full nuclear war. The mechanism of such an effect depends primarily on the injection into the atmosphere of small solid particles, as soot from burning forests, which reflect sunlight and cause a reduction in solar energy retained by the earth.
Having a nucleus; nucleated.

entry.ety: Cf. L. nucleare to become kernelly
entry.def: To gather, as about a nucleus or center.
To form into a nucleus or multiple nuclei; as, raindrops may nucleate around silver iodide crystals.
Having a nucleus; nucleate; as, nucleated cells.

entry.note: The nucleic acids are vital constituents of all living cells, carrying the genetic information propagated between generations, and, while a cell is alive, having a continued function in coding for the amino acid sequence of proteins being synthesized by the cell. The two natural types of nucleic adic are ribonucleic acid RNA) and deoxyribonucleic acid DNA).
entry.def: A natural or synthetic polymer consisting of chains of ribonucleotide or deoxyribonucleotide units.
Formed like a nucleus or kernel.

A constituent of the nuclei of all cells, containing protein and nucleic acid. It is a colorless amorphous substance, readily soluble in alkaline fluids and especially characterized by its comparatively large content of phosphorus. It also contains nitrogen and sulphur.
Belonging to the Nucleobranchiata.
See Heteropoda.
Hyaline plasma contained in the nucleus of vegetable cells.
Of or pertaining to the nucleolus of a cell.
Having a nucleole, or second inner nucleus.
The nucleus within a nucleus; nucleolus.

entries.entry:
Nu*cle"o*lus ☞ It was termed by Agassiz the entoblast. In the protozoa, where it may be situated on one side of the nucleus, it is sometimes called the endoplastule, and is supposed to be concerned in the male part of the reproductive process. See Nucleus. n.; pl.Nucleoli #. L., a little nut, dim. of nucleus
A little nucleus.
Biol A small rounded body contained in the nucleus of a cell or a protozoan.

entry.def: A neutron or proton, when contained within an atomic nucleus.
The sum of the number of neutrons and protons in an atomic nucleus.
The matter composing the nucleus of a cell; the protoplasm of the nucleus; karyoplasma.
Of or pertaining to nucleoplasm; -- esp. applied to a body formed in the developing ovum from the plasma of the nucleus of the germinal vesicle.

A type of molecule found in all living organisms, present mostly in chemically combined form as a component of nucleic acids, and also in smaller amounts in free form, consisting of a pentose sugar bound to a purine or pyrimidine base; two types of nucleoside, ribonucleoside and deoxyribonucleoside, are present. The most common bases present in nucleosides are adenine, cytosine, uracil, guanine, and thymine, and to a lesser extent hypoxanthine and other bases are found. The most commmon ribonucleosides composed from these bases are called adenosine, cytidine, uridine, and guanosine. The forms esterified with orthophosphoric at the 5-position of the pentose are called nucleotides. The nucleotides form the monomer units which are combined into DNA and RNA, which carry the genetic information required for reproduction in all known organisms.
a phosphate ester of a nucleoside; one of the monomeric components of DNA or RNA.

entries.entry:
Nu"cle*us ☞ The nucleus is sometimes termed the endoplast or endoblast, and in the protozoa is supposed to be concerned in the female part of the reproductive process. See Karyokinesis. n.; pl. E. Nucleuses #, L. Nuclei #. L., a kernel, dim. fr. nux nucis, nut. Cf. Newel post
A kernel; hence, a central mass or point about which matter is gathered, or to which accretion is made; the central or material portion; -- used both literally and figuratively. It must contain within itself a nucleus of truth.
Astron The body or the head of a comet.
Bot
An incipient ovule of soft cellular tissue.
A whole seed, as contained within the seed coats.
Biol A body, usually spheroidal, in a eukaryotic cell, distinguished from the surrounding protoplasm by a difference in refrangibility and in behavior towards chemical reagents, which contains the chromosomal genetic material, including the chromosomal DNA. It is more or less protoplasmic, and consists of a clear fluid (achromatin) through which extends a network of fibers (chromatin) in which may be suspended a second rounded body, the nucleolus (see Nucleoplasm). See Cell division, under Division.
Zoöl
The tip, or earliest part, of a univalve or bivalve shell.
The central part around which additional growths are added, as of an operculum.
A visceral mass, containing the stomach and other organs, in Tunicata and some mollusks.

entry.ety: L., little nut, dim. of nux nucis, a nut
entry.def: A genus of small marine bivalve shells, having a pearly interior.
Same as Nutlet.
See Nucamentaceous.

entry.ety: L. nudatio, fr. nudare to make naked, fr. nudus naked. See Nude
entry.def: The act of stripping, or making bare or naked.
To walk quickly with the head bent forward; -- often with along.

cs.cd: the undraped human figure in art.

sn.def: Bare; naked; unclothed; undraped; as, a nude statue.
Naked; without consideration; void; as, a nude contract. See Nudum pactum.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Nudged nŭjd; p. pr. & vb. n. Nudging
entry.ety: Cf. Prov. G. knütschen to squeeze, pinch, E. Knock
entry.def: To touch gently, as with the elbow, in order to call attention or convey intimation.
A gentle push, or jog, as with the elbow.

entry.ety: L. nudus naked + brachium an arm
entry.def: Having tentacles without vibratile cilia.
Of or pertaining to the Nudibranchiata.
A division of opisthobranchiate mollusks, having no shell except while very young. The gills are naked and situated upon the back or sides. See Ceratobranchia.
Same as Nudibranch.
Having the stems leafless.

entry.ety: L. nudus naked + -ficarein comp.) to make. See -fy
entry.def: The act of making nude.

entries.entry:
Nu"di*ty n.; pl.Nudities #. Cf. F. nudité
The quality or state of being nude; nakedness.
That which is nude or naked; naked part; undraped or unclothed portion; esp. Fine Arts the human figure represented unclothed; any representation of nakedness; -- chiefly used in the plural and in a bad sense. There are no such licenses permitted in poetry any more than in painting, to design and color obscene nudities.

entry.def: a pestiferous boring and dull person.

entries.entry: ‖Nu"dum pac"tum. L., a nude pact Law A bare, naked contract, without any consideration and therefore unenforceable in a court of law.

entry.def: Futility; trifling talk or behavior; drollery.
Trifles; jests.
The act or practice of trifling.

entry.ety: L. nugatorius, fr. nugari to trifle, nugae jests, trifles

sn.def: Trifling; vain; futile; insignificant.
Of no force; inoperative; ineffectual.
sn.q: If all are pardoned, and pardoned as a mere act of clemency, the very substance of government is made nugatory.

entry.ety: Earlier niggot, prob. for nigot an ingot. See Ingot

sn.def: A lump; a mass, esp. a native lump of a precious metal; as, a nugget of gold.
Something of value, usually found among many other less valuable things; -- often used figuratively; as, a nugget of useful information in a sea of data.

entry.def: To render trifling or futile; to make silly.

entry.note: ☞ Nuisances are public when they annoy citizens in general; private, when they affect individuals only.
entry.ety: OE. noisance, OF. noisance nuisance, fr. L. nocentia guilt, fr. nocere to hurt, harm; akin to necare to kill. Cf Necromancy Nocent Noxious Pernicious
entry.def: That which annoys or gives trouble and vexation; that which is offensive or noxious.
One who makes or causes a nuisance.
No; not any; as, nul disseizin; nul tort.

entry.ety: L. nullus not any, none; ne not + ullus any, a dim. of unus one; cf. F. nul. See No, and One, and cf. None

sn.def: Of no legal or binding force or validity; of no efficacy; invalid; void; nugatory; useless.
sn.q: Faultily faultless, icily regular, splendidly null, Dead perfection; no more.

sn.def: Having a value of zero; as, of null utility.
Empty; having no members; as, the null set.

Unassigned or meaningless; -- a special value given to variables, especially pointers or logical variables, indicating that it is meaningless and cannot be used in computation; as, an uninitialized pointer in "C" is given a null value. The actual value that is stored in memory to indicate the null condition may vary with the computer language used.

cs.cd: a zero method. See under Zero.

sn.def: Something that has no force or meaning.
That which has no value; a cipher; zero.

entry.ety: From null, a., or perh. abbrev. from annul
entry.def: To annul.
One of the beads in nulled work.

entry.ety: Hind. nālā, fr. Skr. nāla tube
entry.def: A water course, esp. a dry one; a gully; a gorge; -- orig. an East Indian term.

cs.cd: ornamental turned work resembling beads (called nulls) strung on a rod.

entry.def: Turned so as to resemble nulls.
The state or condition of being nowhere.

cs.cd: the right claimed in behalf of a State to nullify or make void, by its sovereign act or decree, an enactment of the general government which it deems unconstitutional.

entry.def: The act of nullifying; a rendering void and of no effect, or of no legal effect.
Of no faith; also, not trusting to faith for salvation; -- opposed to solifidian.
An unbeliever.
One who nullifies or makes void; one who maintains the right to nullify a contract by one of the parties.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Nullified; p. pr. & vb. n. Nullifying
entry.ety: L. nullificare; nullus none + -ficarein comp.) to make. See Null a., and -fy
entry.def: To make void; to render invalid; to deprive of legal force or efficacy.
entry.q: Such correspondence would at once nullify the conditions of the probationary system.
entry.syn: To abrogate; revoke; annul; repeal; invalidate; cancel. See Abolish.

entry.def: A name for certain crustaceous marine algæ which secrete carbonate of lime on their surface, and were formerly thought to be of animal nature. They are now considered corallines of the genera Melobesia and Lithothamnion.

entries.entry:
Nul"li*ty nŭl"lĭ*t� n.; pl.Nullities. LL. nullitias, fr. L. nullus none: cf. F. nullité . See Null
The quality or state of being null; nothingness; want of efficacy or force.
Law Nonexistence; as, a decree of nullity of marriage is a decree that no legal marriage exists.
That which is null. Was it not absurd to say that the convention was supreme in the state, and yet a nullity?

entry.ety: OE. nume nome, prop., seized, taken, p. p. of nimen to take, AS. niman, p. p. numen. √7. See Nimble Nomad, and cf. Benumb

sn.def: Enfeebled in, or destitute of, the power of sensation and motion; rendered torpid; benumbed; insensible; as, the fingers or limbs are numb with cold.
sn.q: A stony image, cold andnumb.

sn.def: Producing numbness; benumbing; as, the numb, cold night.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Numbed nŭmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Numbing nŭm"ĭng
entry.def: To make numb; to deprive of the power of sensation or motion; to render senseless or inert; to deaden; to benumb; to stupefy.
entry.q: For lazy winter numbs the laboring hand.
Like dull narcotics, numbing pain.

entry.def: Numbness.

cs.cd: etc. See under Abstract Abundant, etc.
in numbered parts; as, a book published in numbers.

entry.ety: OE. nombre, F. nombre, L. numerus; akin to Gr. no`mos that which is dealt out, fr. ne`mein to deal out, distribute. See Numb Nomad, and cf. Numerate Numero Numerous

sn.def: That which admits of being counted or reckoned; a unit, or an aggregate of units; a numerable aggregate or collection of individuals; an assemblage made up of distinct things expressible by figures.
A collection of many individuals; a numerous assemblage; a multitude; many.
sn.q: Ladies are always of great use to the party they espouse, and never fail to win over numbers.

sn.def: A numeral; a word or character denoting a number; as, to put a number on a door.
Numerousness; multitude.
sn.q: Number itself importeth not much in armies where the people are of weak courage.

sn.def: The state or quality of being numerable or countable.
sn.q: Of whom came nations, tribes, people, and kindreds out of number.

sn.def: Quantity, regarded as made up of an aggregate of separate things.
That which is regulated by count; poetic measure, as divisions of time or number of syllables; hence, poetry, verse; -- chiefly used in the plural.
sn.q: I lisped in numbers, for the numbers came.

sn.def: The distinction of objects, as one, or more than one (in some languages, as one, or two, or more than two), expressed (usually) by a difference in the form of a word; thus, the singular number and the plural number are the names of the forms of a word indicating the objects denoted or referred to by the word as one, or as more than one.
The measure of the relation between quantities or things of the same kind; that abstract species of quantity which is capable of being expressed by figures; numerical value.

cs.cd: a machine for printing consecutive numbers, as on railway tickets, bank bills, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Numbered nŭm"bẽrd; p. pr & vb. n. Numbering
entry.ety: OE. nombren noumbren, F. nombrer, fr. L. numerare numeratum. See Number n.

sn.def: To count; to reckon; to ascertain the units of; to enumerate.
sn.q: If a man can number the dust of the earth, then shall thy seed also be numbered.

sn.def: To reckon as one of a collection or multitude.
sn.q: He was numbered with the transgressors.

sn.def: To give or apply a number or numbers to; to assign the place of in a series by order of number; to designate the place of by a number or numeral; as, to number the houses in a street, or the apartments in a building.
To amount; to equal in number; to contain; to consist of; as, the army numbers fifty thousand.
sn.q: Thy tears can not number the dead.

entry.def: One who numbers.
Numerous.
Innumerable; countless.
Numerous.
pl. of Number. The fourth book of the Pentateuch, containing the census of the Hebrews.
The torpedo, which numbs by the electric shocks which it gives.
See Nombles.
The condition of being numb; that state of a living body in which it loses, wholly or in part, the power of feeling or motion.
an embroidered rug made from a coarse Indian felt.
A genus of birds comprising certain of the curlews.
skill with numbers and mathematics; -- the skill with numbers analogous to literacy, the skill of reading.

entry.ety: L. numerabilis. See Number v. t.
entry.def: Capable of being numbered or counted.

entry.ety: L. numeralis, fr. numerus number: cf. F. numéral. See Number n.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to number; consisting of number or numerals.
sn.q: A long train of numeral progressions.

sn.def: Expressing number; representing number; as, numeral letters or characters, as X or 10 for ten.
A figure or character used to express a number; as, the Arabic numerals, 1, 2, 3, etc.; the Roman numerals, I, V, X, L, etc.
A word expressing a number.

entry.def: According to number; in number; numerically.
Belonging to a certain number; counting as one of a collection or body.
entry.q: A supernumerary canon, when he obtains a prebend, becomes a numerary canon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Numerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Numerating
entry.ety: L. numeratus, p. p. of numerare to count. See Number v.
entry.def: To divide off and read according to the rules of numeration; as, to numerate a row of figures.

entry.note: ☞ For convenience in reading, numbers are usually separated by commas into periods of three figures each, as 1,155,465; in continental Europe, periods are used for a similar division. According to what is called the “English” system, the billion is a million of millions, a trillion a million of billions, and each higher denomination is a million times the one preceding. According to the system of the French and other Continental nations and also that of the United States, the billion is a thousand millions, and each higher denomination is a thousand times the preceding.
entry.ety: L. numeratio a counting out: cf. F. numération

sn.def: The act or art of numbering.
sn.q: Numeration is but still the adding of one unit more, and giving to the whole a new name or sign.

sn.def: The act or art of reading numbers when expressed by means of numerals. The term is almost exclusively applied to the art of reading numbers written in the scale of tens, by the Arabic method.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to numeration; as, a numerative system.

entry.note: ☞ In a vulgar fraction the numerator is written above a line; thus, in the fraction 5/9five ninths) 5 is the numerator; in a decimal fraction it is the number which follows the decimal point. See Fraction.

sn.def: One who numbers.
The term in a fraction which indicates the number of fractional units that are taken.

entry.note: ☞ Numerical, as opposed to algebraical, is used to denote a value irrespective of its sign; thus, -5 is numerically greater than -3, though algebraically less.

cs.cd: an equation which has all the quantities except the unknown expressed in numbers; -- distinguished from literal equation.
of an equation or expression, that deduced by substituting numbers for the letters, and reducing.

entry.ety: Cf. F. numérique. See Number n.

sn.def: Belonging to number; denoting number; consisting in numbers; expressed by numbers, and not letters; as, numerical characters; a numerical equation; a numerical statement.
The same in number; hence, identically the same; identical; as, the same numerical body.
sn.q: Would to God that all my fellow brethren, which with me bemoan the loss of their books, . . . might rejoice for the recovery thereof, though not the same numerical volumes.

sn.def: relating to or having ability to think in or work with numbers; as, tests for rating numerical aptitude. Contrasted with verbal.

entry.def: Any number, proper or improper fraction, or incommensurable ratio. The term also includes any imaginary expression like m + n√-1, where m and n are real numerics.
In a numerical manner; in numbers; with respect to number, or sameness in number; as, a thing is numerically the same, or numerically different.
One who deals in numbers.

entry.ety: It., or F. numéro ; both fr. L. numerus number
entry.def: Number; -- often abbrev. No.

sn.def: The state of being numerous; numerousness.
Rhythm; harmony; flow.
sn.q: The numerosity of the sentence pleased the ear.

sn.def: Consisting of a great number of units or individual objects; being many; as, a numerous army; numerous objections.
sn.q: Such and so numerous was their chivalry.

sn.def: Consisting of poetic numbers; rhythmical; measured and counted; melodious; musical.
sn.q: Such prompt eloquence Flowed from their lips, in prose or numerous verse.

entry.cs: Numidian crane. Zoöl See Demoiselle, 2.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to ancient Numidia in Northern Africa.
A subfamily of birds including the guinea fowl and related birds of Africa and Madagascar.

sn.def: Evincing the presence of a deity; as, a numinous wood; the most numinous moment in the Mass.
same as supernatural.

entry.ety: L. numisma nomisma, a piece of money, coin, fr. Gr. � anything sanctioned by usage, the current coin, fr. � to introduce a custom, or usage, fr. no`mos a custom, or usage, fr. ne`mein to distribute, assign: cf. F. numismatique. See Nomad
entry.def: Of or pertaining to coins; relating to the science of coins or medals.
The science of coins and medals.
One skilled in numismatics; a numismatologist.
A treatise on, or description of, coins and medals.
One versed in numismatology; usually called a numismatist.
The science which treats of coins and medals, in their relation to history; numismatics.

entry.ety: L. nummarius, from nummus a coin
entry.def: Of or relating to coins or money.

entry.ety: L. nummularius, fr. nummulus, dim. of nummus a coin: cf. F. nummulaire

sn.def: Of or pertaining to coin or money; pecuniary; as, the nummulary talent.
Having the appearance or form of a coin.
sn.q: Nummularsputa.

entry.def: The arrangement of the red blood corpuscles in rouleaux, like piles of coins, as when a drop of human blood is examined under the microscope.

entry.ety: L. nummus a coin + -lite: cf. F. nummulite
entry.def: A fossil of the genus Nummulites and allied genera.
A genus of extinct Tertiary Foraminifera, having a thin, flat, round shell, containing a large number of small chambers arranged spirally.
Of, like, composed of, containing, nummulites; as, nummulitic beds.
A dolt; a blockhead.
A dunce; a dolt; a stupid fellow.
entry.q: They have talked like numskulls.

entry.def: Stupid; doltish.

entry.cs: Gray nuns R. C. Ch the members of a religious order established in Montreal in 1745, whence branches were introduced into the United States in 1853; -- so called from the color or their robe, and known in religion as Sisters of Charity of Montreal. Nun buoy. See under Buoy.
entry.ety: OE. nunne, AS. nunne, fr. L. nonna nun, nonnus monk; cf. Gr. �, �; of unknown origin. Cf. Nunnery

sn.def: A woman devoted to a religious life, who lives in a convent, under the three vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience.
sn.q: They holy time is quiet as a nun Breathless with adoration.

sd.def: A white variety of domestic pigeons having a veil of feathers covering the head.
The smew.
The European blue titmouse.

entry.def: The 14th letter of the Hebrew alphabet, corresponding in pronunciation to n.
The 25th letter of the Arabic alphabet, corresponding in pronunciation to n.

entries.entry:
Nu"na*tak n.; pl. -taks #the pl. form Nunatakker is Swedish). Eskimo nunættak
In Greenland, an insular hill or mountain surrounded by an ice sheet.
‖Nunc" di*mit"tis. L. nunc now + dimittis thou lettest depart Eccl The song of Simeon Luke ii. 29-32), used in the ritual of many churches. It begins with these words in the Vulgate.

entry.ety: OE. nonechenche, for noneschenche, prop., a noon drink; none noon + schenchen schenken skinken, to pour, AS. scencan. See Noon, and Skink v. i.
entry.def: A portion of food taken at or after noon, usually between full meals; a luncheon.
One who announces; a messenger; a nuncio.

entry.ety: L. nunciare nuntiare, to announce, report, fr. nuncius nuntius, messenger: cf. F. nonciature, It. nunziatura. See Nuncio
entry.def: The office of a nuncio.

entries.entry:
Nun"ci*o n.; pl.Nuncios #. It. nunzio nuncio, fr. L. nuncius nuntius, messenger; perh. akin to novus new, E. new, and thus, one who brings news. Cf. Announce
A messenger. Obs
The permanent official representative of the pope at a foreign court or seat of government. Distinguished from a legate a latere, whose mission is temporary in its nature, or for some special purpose. Nuncios are of higher rank than internuncios.
‖Nun"ci*us n.; pl.Nuncii #. L Roman & Old Eng. Law A messenger. The information communicated.

entry.ety: L. nuncupatus, p. p. of nuncupare to nuncupate, prob. fr. nomen name + capere to take

sn.def: To declare publicly or solemnly; to proclaim formally.
sn.q: In whose presence did St. Peter nuncupate it?

sn.def: To dedicate by declaration; to inscribe; as, to nuncupate a book.

entry.def: The act of nuncupating.

cs.cd: a will or testament made by word of mouth only, before witnesses, as by a soldier or seaman, and depending on oral testimony for proof.

entry.ety: L. nuncupativus nominal: cf. F. nuncupatif

sn.def: Publicly or solemnly declaratory.
Nominal; existing only in name.
Oral; not written.

entry.def: Nuncupative; oral.
A nundinal letter.

cs.cd: among the Romans, one of the first eight letters of the alphabet, which were repeated successively from the first to the last day of the year. One of these always expressed the market day, which returned every nine days (every eight days by our reckoning).

entry.ety: L. nundinalis nundinarius, fr. nundinae the market day, the weekly market, prop., the ninth day, fr. nundinus belonging to nine days; novem nine + dies day: cf. F. nundinal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a fair, or to a market day.

entry.ety: L. nundinatus, p. p. of nundinary to attend fairs, to traffic. See Nundinal a.
entry.def: To buy and sell at fairs or markets.
Traffic at fairs; marketing; buying and selling.
entry.q: Common nundination of pardons.

entry.ety: From nun, the Arabic name of the letter n: cf. NL. nunnatio, F. nunnation
entry.def: The pronunciation of n at the end of words.

entries.entry:
Nun"ner*y n.; pl.Nunneries #. OE. nonnerie, OF. nonerie, F. nonnerie, fr. nonne nun, L. nonna. See Nun
A house in which nuns reside; a cloister or convent in which women reside for life, under religious vows. See Cloister, and Convent.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling a nun; characteristic of a nun.
Same as Nupson.
A genus of plants found in the fresh-water ponds or lakes of Europe, Asia, and North America; the yellow water lily. Cf. Nymphaea.
A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicine used to relieve the pain of arthritis and as an analgesic and antipyretic; Advil and Motrin and Nuprin are trademarks of brands of ibuprofen tablets.
entry.syn: ibuprofen, isobutylphenyl propionic acid, Advil, Motrin.

entry.def: A simpleton; a fool.

entry.ety: L. nuptialis, fr. nuptiae marriage, wedding, fr. nubere nuptum, prop., to cover, to veil, hence, to marry, as the head of the bride was covered with a veil; cf. Gr. � bride, nymph: cf. F. nuptial
entry.def: Of or pertaining to marriage; done or used at a wedding; as, nuptial rites and ceremonies.
entry.q: Then, all in heat, They light the nuptial torch.

entries.entry: Nup"tial n.; pl.Nuptials nŭp"sh�lz. Marriage; wedding; nuptial ceremony; -- now only in the plural. Celebration of that nuptial, which We two have sworn shall come. Preparations . . . for the approaching nuptials.

entry.def: A hard knot in wood; also, a hard knob of wood used by boys in playing hockey.
entry.q: I think I'm as hard as a nur, and as tough as whitleather.

entry.mhw: ‖Nu*ra"ghe n.; It. pl. -ghi . Also Nu"ragh, etc
entry.def: One of the prehistoric towerlike structures found in Sardinia.
entry.q: The so-called nuraghi, conical monuments with truncated summits, 30-60 ft. in height, 35-100 ft. in diameter at the base, constructed sometimes of hewn, and sometimes of unhewn blocks of stone without mortar. They are situated either on isolated eminences or on the slopes of the mountains, seldom on the plains, and usually occur in groups. They generally contain two (in some rare instances three) conically vaulted chambers, one above the other, and a spiral staircase constructed in the thick walls ascends to the upper stories.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Nurled nûrld; p. pr. & vb. n. Nurling
entry.def: To cut with reeding or fluting on the edge of, as coins, the heads of screws, etc.; to knurl.

entry.cs:
Nurse shark. Zoöl A large arctic shark (Somniosus microcephalus), having small teeth and feeble jaws; -- called also sleeper shark, and ground shark. A large shark (Ginglymostoma cirratum), native of the West Indies and Gulf of Mexico, having the dorsal fins situated behind the ventral fins.
To put to nurseorTo put out to nurse
to send away to be nursed; to place in the care of a nurse.
Wet nurse Dry nurse . See Wet nurse, and Dry nurse, in the Vocabulary.
entry.ety: OE. nourse nurice norice, OF. nurrice norrice nourrice, F. nourrice, fr. L. nutricia nurse, prop., fem. of nutricius that nourishes; akin to nutrix -icis, nurse, fr. nutrire to nourish. See Nourish, and cf. Nutritious

sn.def: One who nourishes; a person who supplies food, tends, or brings up; as: A woman who has the care of young children; especially, one who suckles an infant not her own. A person, especially a woman, who has the care of the sick or infirm.
One who, or that which, brings up, rears, causes to grow, trains, fosters, or the like.
sn.q: The nurse of manly sentiment and heroic enterprise.

sn.def: A lieutenant or first officer, who is the real commander when the captain is unfit for his place.

sd.def: A peculiar larva of certain trematodes which produces cercariæ by asexual reproduction. See Cercaria, and Redia.
Either one of the nurse sharks.

cs.cd: to strike them gently and so as to keep them in good position during a series of caroms.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Nursed; p. pr. & vb. n. Nursing
entry.sn:
To nourish; to cherish; to foster; as: To nourish at the breast; to suckle; to feed and tend, as an infant.
To take care of or tend, as a sick person or an invalid; to attend upon. Sons wont to nurse their parents in old age. Him in Egerian groves Aricia bore, And nursed his youth along the marshy shore.

sn.def: To bring up; to raise, by care, from a weak or invalid condition; to foster; to cherish; -- applied to plants, animals, and to any object that needs, or thrives by, attention.
sn.q: Tonursethe saplings tall.
By what hands [has vice] been nursed into so uncontrolled a dominion?

sn.def: To manage with care and economy, with a view to increase; as, to nurse our national resources.
To caress; to fondle, as a nurse does.

entry.def: fed mother's milk from the breast; -- of an infant.
See Houndfish.
An infant considered in relation to its nurse.
A girl or woman employed to attend and care for children.
A pond where fish are fed.
One who nurses; a nurse; one who cherishes or encourages growth.

entries.entry:
Nurs"er*y n.; pl.Nurseries #. Cf. F. nourricerie
The act of nursing. Obs Her kindnursery.
The place where nursing is carried on; as: The place, or apartment, in a house, appropriated to the care of children.
A place where young of any species, plant or animal, are nourished preparatory to transfer elsewhere; especially a place where young trees, shrubs, vines, etc., are propagated for the purpose of transplanting; a plantation of young trees.
The place where anything is fostered and growth promoted. Fair Padua,nurseryof arts. Christian families are the nurseries of the church on earth, as she is the nursery of the church in heaven.
That which forms and educates; as, commerce is the nursery of seamen.
That which is nursed. R
Nurs"er*y*man n.; pl.Nurserymen. One who cultivates or keeps a nursery, or place for rearing trees, etc.

entry.def: Supplying or taking nourishment from, or as from, the breast; as, a nursing mother; a nursing infant.
One who, or that which, is nursed; an infant; a fondling.
entry.q: I was his nursling once, and choice delight.

entry.def: To nurse. See Noursle.

entry.ety: OE. norture noriture, OF. norriture norreture, F. nourriture, fr. L. nutritura a nursing, suckling. See Nourish

sn.def: The act of nourishing or nursing; tender care; education; training.
sn.q: A man neither by nature nor by nurture wise.

sn.def: That which nourishes; food; diet.

entry.usage: To Nurture Nourish Cherish. Nourish denotes to supply with food, or cause to grow; as, to nourish a plant, to nourish rebellion. To nurture is to train up with a fostering care, like that of a mother; as, to nurture into strength; to nurture in sound principles. To cherish is to hold and treat as dear; as, to cherish hopes or affections.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Nurtured; p. pr. & vb. n. Nurturing

sn.def: To feed; to nourish.
To educate; to bring or train up.
sn.q: He was nurtured where he had been born.
sn.syn: To nourish; nurse; cherish; bring up; educate; tend.

entry.def: The god of fire and light; corresponds to the Babylonian Girru.
To fondle; to cherish.

entry.cs:
Check nut Jam nut Lock nut
a nut which is screwed up tightly against another nut on the same bolt or screw, in order to prevent accidental unscrewing of the first nut. Nut buoy. See under Buoy. Nut coal screened coal of a size smaller than stove coal and larger than pea coal; -- called also chestnut coal. Nut crab Zoöl any leucosoid crab of the genus Ebalia as, Ebalia tuberosa of Europe. Nut grass Bot See nut grass in the vocabulary. Nut lock a device, as a metal plate bent up at the corners, to prevent a nut from becoming unscrewed, as by jarring.
Nut pine. Bot See under Pine. Nut rush Bot a genus of cyperaceous plants (Scleria) having a hard bony achene. Several species are found in the United States and many more in tropical regions. Nut tree a tree that bears nuts. Nut weevil Zoöl any species of weevils of the genus Balaninus and other allied genera, which in the larval state live in nuts.
entry.ety: OE. nute note, AS. hnutu; akin to D. noot, G. nuss, OHG. nuz, Icel. hnot, Sw. nöt, Dan. nöd

sn.def: The fruit of certain trees and shrubs (as of the almond, walnut, hickory, beech, filbert, etc.), consisting of a hard and indehiscent shell inclosing a kernel.

A perforated block (usually a small piece of metal), provided with an internal or female screw thread, used on a bolt, or screw, for tightening or holding something, or for transmitting motion. See Illust. of 1st Bolt.
The tumbler of a gunlock.
A projection on each side of the shank of an anchor, to secure the stock in place.
Testicles.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Nutted; p. pr. & vb. n. Nutting
entry.def: To gather nuts.

entry.ety: L. nutans, p. pr. of nutare to nod, v. intens. fr. nuerein comp.) to nod; cf. Gr. �
entry.def: Nodding; having the top bent downward.
to rock, sway, or nod; usually involuntarily.

entry.ety: L. nutatio a nodding, fr. nutare to nod: cf. F. nutation

sn.def: The act of nodding.
sn.q: So from the midmost the nutation spreads, Round and more round, o'er all the sea of heads.

sn.def: A very small libratory motion of the earth's axis, by which its inclination to the plane of the ecliptic is constantly varying by a small amount.

sd.def: The motion of a flower in following the apparent movement of the sun, from the east in the morning to the west in the evening.
Circumnutation.

entry.def: The European nuthatch.
The nutcracker.
Brown as a nut long kept and dried.
entry.q: The spicynutbrownale.

sn.def: An instrument for cracking nuts.

sd.def: A European bird (Nucifraga caryocatactes), allied to the magpie and crow. Its color is dark brown, spotted with white. It feeds on nuts, seeds, and insects.
The American, or Clarke's, nutcracker (Picicorvus Columbianus) of Western North America.

entry.def: A more or less round gall resembling a nut, esp. one of those produced on the oak and used in the arts. See Gall Gallnut.

A widely distributed perennial plant of the Sedge family (Cyperus rotundus, var. Hydra), which has slender rootstocks bearing small, edible, nutlike tubers, by which the plant multiplies exceedingly, especially in cotton fields.

Any one of several species of birds of the genus Sitta, as the European species (Sitta Europæa). The white-breasted nuthatch Sitta Carolinensis), the red-breasted nuthatch Sitta Canadensis), the pygmy nuthatch Sitta pygmæa), and others, are American.

sn.def: A hook at the end of a pole to pull down boughs for gathering the nuts.
A thief who steals by means of a hook; also, a bailiff who hooks or seizes malefactors.

entry.def: The nuthatch.
A small nut; also, the stone of a drupe.

entry.note: ☞ This fruit is a nearly spherical drupe, of the size of a pear, of a yellowish color without and almost white within. This opens into two nearly equal longitudinal valves, inclosing the nut surrounded by its aril, which is mace. The nutmeg is an aromatic, very grateful to the taste and smell, and much used in cookery. Other species of Myristica yield nutmegs of inferior quality.
entry.cs:
American nutmeg Calabash nutmegorJamaica nutmeg
the fruit of a tropical shrub (Monodora Myristica). It is about the size of an orange, and contains many aromatic seeds imbedded in pulp. Brazilian nutmeg the fruit of a lauraceous tree, Cryptocarya moschata. California nutmeg a tree of the Yew family (Torreya Californica), growing in the Western United States, and having a seed which resembles a nutmeg in appearance, but is strongly impregnated with turpentine. Clove nutmeg the Ravensara aromatica, a lauraceous tree of Madagascar. The foliage is used as a spice, but the seed is acrid and caustic. Jamaica nutmeg. See American nutmeg (above). Nutmeg bird Zoöl an Indian finch (Munia punctularia). Nutmeg butter a solid oil extracted from the nutmeg by expression. Nutmeg flower Bot a ranunculaceous herb (Nigella sativa) with small black aromatic seeds, which are used medicinally and for excluding moths from furs and clothing. Nutmeg liver Med a name applied to the liver, when, as the result of heart or lung disease, it undergoes congestion and pigmentation about the central veins of its lobules, giving it an appearance resembling that of a nutmeg. Nutmeg melon Bot a small variety of muskmelon of a rich flavor. Nutmeg pigeon Zoöl any one of several species of pigeons of the genus Myristicivora, native of the East Indies and Australia. The color is usually white, or cream-white, with black on the wings and tail. Nutmeg wood Bot the wood of the Palmyra palm. Peruvian nutmeg the aromatic seed of a South American tree (Laurelia sempervirens). Plume nutmeg Bot a spicy tree of Australia (Atherosperma moschata).
entry.ety: OE. notemuge; note nut + OF. muge musk, of the same origin as E. musk; cf. OF. noix muguette nutmeg, F. noix muscade. See Nut, and Musk
entry.def: The kernel of the fruit of the nutmeg tree Myristica fragrans), a native of the Molucca Islands, but cultivated elsewhere in the tropics.
Seasoned with nutmeg.
The nuthatch.

entry.ety: Sp. nutria an otter, fr. L. lutra lytra
entry.def: The fur of the coypu. See Coypu.

entry.ety: L. nutricatio, fr. nutricare nutricari, to suckle, nourish, fr. nutrix a nurse
entry.def: The act or manner of feeding.

entry.ety: L. nutriens, p. pr. of nutrire. See Nourish
entry.def: Nutritious; nourishing; promoting growth.

sn.def: Any substance which has nutritious qualities, i. e., which nourishes or promotes growth; a nutriment.
A substance added to the growth medium of a microorganism to promote growth.

entry.def: To give nutrients to.

entry.ety: L. nutrimentum, fr. nutrire to nourish. See Nourish

sn.def: That which nourishes; a nutrient; anything which promotes growth and repairs the natural waste of animal or vegetable life; food; aliment.
sn.q: The stomach returns what it has received, in strength and nutriment diffused into all parts of the body.

sn.def: That which promotes development or growth.
sn.q: Is not virtue in mankind The nutriment that feeds the mind?

entry.def: Nutritious.
Pertaining to, or connected with, nutrition; nutritious.

entry.note: ☞ In this wide sense it comprehends digestion absorption circulation assimilation, etc., in fact all of the steps by which the nutritive matter of the food is fitted for incorporation with the different tissues, and the changes which it undergoes after its assimilation, prior to its excretion. See Metabolism.

sn.def: In the broadest sense, a process or series of processes by which a living organism as a whole (or its component parts or organs) is maintained in its normal condition of life and growth.
In a more limited sense, the process by which the living tissues take up, from the blood, matters necessary either for their repair or for the performance of their healthy functions.
That which nourishes; nutriment.
sn.q: Fixed like a plant, on his peculiar spot, To draw nutrition, propagate, and rot.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to nutrition; as, nutritional changes.
a specialist in the study of nutrition.

entry.ety: L. nutricius nutritius, from nutrix -icis, a nurse, nutrire to nourish. See Nurse Nourish
entry.def: Nourishing; promoting growth, or preventing decay; alimental.

entry.cs: Nutritive plasma. Biol See Idioplasma. Nutritive polyp Zoöl any one of the zooids of a compound hydroid, or coral, which has a mouth and digestive cavity.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to nutrition; as, the nutritive functions; having the quality of nourishing; nutritious; nutrimental; alimental; as, nutritive food or berries.

entry.ety: L. nutritura, fr. nutrire to nourish
entry.def: Nutrition; nourishment.
Crazy; loony; insane; batty; -- used in a predicate position, ususually in phrases such as to go nuts went nuts, are you nuts?
An expression of disapproval, defiance, or displeasure, as in: “Ah, nuts! My knife just broke.”
a widely distributed perennial sedge (Cyperus rotundus) having small edible nutlike tubers; also called nut grass.

entry.cs:
in a nutshell in a summarized and very abbreviated form; -- of statments, descriptions, reports, and other communications; as, to describe the convention in a nutshell .
To be in a nutshellorTo lie in a nutshell
to be within a small compass; to admit of very brief or simple determination or statement. “The remedy lay in a nutshell.” Macaulay.

sn.def: The shell or hard external covering in which the kernel of a nut is inclosed.
Hence, a thing of little compass, or of little value.
A shell of the genus Nucula.

entry.def: A gatherer of nuts.
The act of gathering nuts.

sn.def: Abounding in nuts.
Having a flavor like that of nuts; as, nutty wine.
Crazy; insane; loony; batty; nuts.

entries.entry: Nux` vom"i*ca. NL., fr. L. nux a nut + vomere to vomit The seed of Strychnos Nuxvomica, a tree which abounds on the Malabar and Coromandel coasts of the East Indies. From this seed the deadly poisons known as strychnine and brucine are obtained. The seeds are sometimes called Quaker buttons.

entry.def: A genus consisting of only one species.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Nuzzled nŭz"z'ld;p. pr. & vb. n. Nuzzling nŭz"zlĭng

sn.def: To noursle or nurse; to foster; to bring up.
sn.q: The people had been nuzzled in idolatry.

sn.ety: Perh. a corruption of nestle. Cf. Nustle
sn.def: To nestle; to house, as in a nest.
To work with the nose, like a swine in the mud.
sn.q: And nuzzling in his flank, the loving swine Sheathed, unaware, the tusk in his soft groin.
He charged through an army of lawyers, sometimes . . . nuzzling like an eel in the mud.

sn.def: To go with head poised like a swine, with nose down.
sn.q: Sir Roger shook his ears, and nuzzled along.

sn.def: To hide the head, as a child in the mother's bosom; to nestle.
To loiter; to idle.

entries.entry:
Ny. Contr. fr. ne I
Not I; nor I. Obs

entry.def: Nigh.
A spiral-horned South African antelope (Tragelaphus angasi) with a fringe of white hairs along back and neck.
See Nias.
A genus consisting of only one species.

entry.note: ☞ Some writers (as Quain) use the word in the opposite sense, night blindness. See Hemeralopia.
entry.ety: L. nyctalopia, fr. nyctalops a nyctalops, Gr. nykta`lwps. Gr. nykta`lwps meant, a person affected either with day blindness or with night blindness, and in the former case was derived fr. ny`x nykto`s, night + 'w`ps 'wpo`s, the eye; in the latter, fr. ny`x + 'alao`s blind + 'w`ps
entry.def: A disease of the eye, in consequence of which the patient can see well in a faint light or at twilight, but is unable to see during the day or in a strong light; day blindness.
See Moonblink.
One afflicted with nyctalopia.
Same as Nyctalopia.
The natural day and night, or space of twenty-four hours.
A South American bird of the genus Nyctibius, allied to the goatsuckers.
A genus of East Indian fruit bats.

entry.note: ☞ Nyctitropic movements of plants usually consist in a folding or drooping of the leaves, the advantage being in lessening the radiation of heat.
entry.ety: From Gr. ny`x nykto`s, night + � turning
entry.def: Turning or bending at night into special positions.

entry.ety: From Gr. ny`x nykto`s, night + � to turn
entry.def: The tendency of certain plant organs, as leaves, to assume special “sleeping” positions or make curvatures under the influence of darkness. It is well illustrated in the leaflets of clover and other leguminous plants.

entry.ety: Gr. ny`x nykto`s, night + � to love
entry.def: Any Australian bat of the genus Nyctophilus, having a very simple nasal appendage.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. F. nid nest, brood, L. nidus nest. See Nest, and cf. Eye brood, Nide
entry.def: A brood or flock of pheasants.

A carnivorous mammal (Helictis moscatus, or Helictis orientalis), native of Eastern Asia and the Indies. It has a dorsal white stripe, and another one across the shoulders. It has a strong musky odor.
Same as nylghau.
entry.syn: nilgai, nylghau, blue bull, Boselaphus tragocamelus.

entry.ety: Hind. & Per. nīlgāw, prop., a blue cow; Per. nīl blue + gāw cow. See Lilac, and Cow the animal
entry.def: A large Asiatic antelope (Boselaphus tragocamelus, syn. Portax tragocamelus), found in Northern India; called also the blue bull. It has short horns, a black mane, and a bunch of long hair on the throat. The general color is grayish brown; the male is blue-grey with white markings, and the female is brownish with no horns.
entry.syn: nilgai, nylghai, blue bull, Boselaphus tragocamelus.

sn.def: Any of several thermoplastic polyamide plastics, comprising a family of high-strength resilient synthetic materials, used mostly in fibers.
A synthetic fabric consisting of fibers of nylon[wn1].
Stockings made of a thin form of nylon{2}, especially full-length stockings either sheer of of varying shades.

entry.ety: L. nympha nymph, bride, young woman, Gr. ny`mfh: cf. F. nymphe. Cf. Nuptial

sn.def: A goddess of the mountains, forests, meadows, or waters.
sn.q: Where were ye, nymphs, when the remorseless deep Closed o'er the head of your loved Lycidas?

sn.def: A lovely young girl; a maiden; a damsel.
sn.q: Nymph, in thy orisons Be all my sins remembered.

sn.def: The pupa of an insect; a chrysalis.
Any one of a subfamily (Najades) of butterflies including the purples, the fritillaries, the peacock butterfly, etc.; -- called also naiad.

entries.entry:
‖nym"pha n.; pl.Nymphæ #. L. See Nymph a goddess
Zoöl Same as Nymph, 3.
pl. Anat Two folds of mucous membrane, within the labia, at the opening of the vulva.

entry.note: ☞ Recent critics have endeavored to show that this genus should be called Castalia, and the name Nymphæa transferred to what is now known as Nuphar.
entry.def: A genus of aquatic plants having showy flowers (white, blue, pink, or yellow, often fragrant), including the white water lily and the Egyptia lotus.
A natural family of dicot aquatic plants.
Of or pertaining to a nymph or nymphs; nymphean.
Same as Nymphalidae, an extensive family of butterflies including the nymphs, the satyrs, the monarchs, the heliconias, and others; -- called also brush-footed butterflies.

Any butterfly of the family Nymphalidae, consisting of medium to large butterflies found worldwide, typically having brightly colored wings and much-reduced nonfunctional forelegs carried folded on the breast.
entry.syn: nymphalid butterfly, brush-footed butterfly, four-footed butterfly.

entry.def: A natural family of large beautifully colored butterflies, called also the brush-footed butterflies; formerly called Nymphales.
The type genus of the Nymphalidae, including the mourning cloak butterfly (Nymphalis antiopa).
Of, pertaining to, or appropriate to, nymphs; inhabited by nymphs; as, a nymphean cave.
A little or young nymph.
entry.q: Thenymphetssporting there.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to nymphs.
Producing pupas or nymphs.
Relating to nymphs; ladylike.
entry.q: Nymphishwar.

entry.def: Resembling, or characteristic of, a nymph.
A nymphomaniac.

entry.ety: Gr. ny`mfh a nymph + lamba`nein to seize
entry.def: A species of demoniac enthusiasm or possession coming upon one who had accidentally looked upon a nymph; ecstasy.
entry.q: The nympholepsy of some fond despair.

entry.def: Under the influence of nympholepsy; ecstatic; frenzied.

entry.ety: Gr. ny`mfh a bride + mani`a madness
entry.def: An uncontrollable excessive sexual desire in women, constituting a true disease.
A woman afflicted with nymphomania.
Same as Nymphomania.
Excision of the nymphæ.

entries.entry: Nys. Is not. See Nis.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � drowsiness, fr. � to nod in sleep, to slumber
entry.def: A rapid involuntary oscillation of the eyeballs.

entry.ety: From NY state + -in, due to its discovery in New York State
entry.def: An antifungal antibiotic, extracted from fermentation broths of the soil actinomycete Streptomyces noursei and other actinomycetes; called also fungicidin. It is a polyene macrolide antibiotic, and consists of several related components. Component nystatin A1 has formula C47H75NO17.
A species of ichneumon (Herpestes nyula). Its fur is beautifully variegated by closely set zigzag markings.
